subject: Re: [junit] JUnit Design?
msgSnippet: ... One difference between SuiteRunner s and JUnit s design that I believe Eric Armstrong didn t hit on is that JUnit s Test interface has a run method, a way
messageBody:
On Thursday, March 20, 2003, at 08:29 AM, Vladimir R. Bossicard wrote:
>
> Someone pointed out a few months ago that the JUnit tests are not
> executed in
> the same order depending on the vm used. If your tests are
> order-dependant it's
> also an issue.
>
> Considering that you have simple ways to share resources, I wonder if
> having one
> test object and invoking all of its test methods is the best solution.
>
One difference between SuiteRunner's and JUnit's design that I believe
Eric Armstrong didn't hit on is that JUnit's Test interface has a run
method, a way to run one test. That pretty much dictates that each test
will run in its own instance. SuiteRunner's Suite class has an execute
method, which executes an *entire suite of tests*, not just one test.
Suite provides a default implementation of the execute method, but it
can be overridden.

The default method discovers and invokes the test methods "in no
particular order" on itself (i.e., the same instance), and executes
each sub-Suite. But if you want those test methods to be invoked in a
particular order, you can override execute (or executeTestMethods) in
your subclass. Or if you want your test methods to each be invoked in a
separate instance a la JUnit, you can override execute and do it the
JUnit way. As I pointed out to Jacob in my reply to his "JUnit and test
data" post earlier this week, another thing you can do is override
execute to drive tests from data read in from a database or file,
rather than using test methods at all. The first time I actually
overrode execute in a Suite subclass was to create
org.suiterunner.JUnitSuite, a package access Suite subclass that
executes a suite of JUnit tests. In other words, I implemented running
JUnit tests from SuiteRunner by creating a Suite subclass whose execute
method knows how to run JUnit tests.

I attempted to provide a default implementation of execute in Suite
that I figured would be useful 90% of the time, but tried to leave the
door open for subclasses to execute suites of tests in any other way
that suits their designer. That was one big "refactor" of JUnit's
design that I did in SuiteRunner, because I felt the run method of
JUnit's Test interface doesn't allow for much flexibility in the way
suites of tests are executed.
